content: I just watched a slide show of pictures taken from the Hubble telescope and it got me back to thinking of how insignificant and powerless we really are in the broader scope of things. And yet some people will insist we are all there is. one of the pictures showed a Galaxie which was one million light years away. To figure that distance one has to consider an object moving at 186,000 miles per second for one year then multiply that number by one million. Quite a distance mind boggling, and thats only what the Hubble was able to see. Whats beyond that? And all in between Hundreds of trillions of tiny specks, Us being no more than one of those specks. So now with that said how could it even be in the realm of possibility that we alone are the only life form in this incalcuable vastness. And still further what makes it so hard to concieve that we have not been visited? Just the mention of Aliens brings ridicule and discredit. Why? Is humanity that backward or are some that clever with the ability to control the masses. Its humbling to say the least and makes me feel powerless and super insignificant when I give thought to this subject which is limitless. Does Anyone believe we have not been visited? and what do you base your belief on?

title: Are we alone?

content: Hubble is awesome. All the money and effert to get it into space and repaired were well worth it. Are we alone? Probably not. Somewhere in the vastness of the galiuxy, among the billions of planets, there is another, as Star Trek would say, "Class M" planet capable of supporting life as we know it. If not, other life forms adapted to other worlds must, by the law of averages exist. As far as extraterrestrials visiting Earth, I'm not so sure. No concrete evidence exists. And carvings of men wearing "space helmets" in Puru or the like have not convinced me...yet...

content: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: Hubble is awesome. All the money and effert to get it into space and repaired were well worth it. Are we alone? Probably not. Somewhere in the vastness of the galiuxy, among the billions of planets, there is another, as Star Trek would say, "Class M" planet capable of supporting life as we know it. If not, other life forms adapted to other worlds must, by the law of averages exist. As far as extraterrestrials visiting Earth, I'm not so sure. No concrete evidence exists. And carvings of men wearing "space helmets" in Puru or the like have not convinced me...yet... considering that were a relatively young planet and and only a matter of years into our space explorations and how far we have come landing men on a planet I find it hard to believe that far older Advanced civilizations dont navigate space as we use highways. And that over the many thousands of years havent dropped in if only out of curiousity from time to time during our exsistance. Imagine the ramifications to the civilized world if it were revealed to be true.

content: Now if NASA were to point Hubble in the direction of the Ford Galaxie there's no telling what they might discover.

title: Are we alone?

content: I've always thought that there's no mathematical way to argue against other civilizations in our own galaxy. But the space between them, the age of the universe and the general tendencies of civilizations to blow themselves up are too much to overcome. There may be infinite civilizations, with infinite hurdles in place to make sure they never interact. One thing is for sure, if there is an active civilization in our galaxy with the capability of visiting us, they'd be light years ahead of us technologically. They probably wouldn't need landing lights or probes in uncomfortable places to do whatever it is they would be doing here.
reply: I've always thought that there's no mathematical way to argue against other civilizations in our own galaxy. content: Glad to see reasoned answers to this topic. Something has definitely been up since the early '50s. Some infamous stories that have been ridiculed or 'debunked' hold up to scrutiny. It's indeed impossible that a planet as primitive as ours has not been visited -- considering the number of planets there are.
reply: Glad to see reasoned answers to this topic. Something has definitely been up since the early '50s. Some infamous stories that have been ridiculed or 'debunked' hold up to scrutiny. content: Likelihood of life bearing planets in the Galaxy? Good to excellent. Likelihood of someone visiting our planet? Thankfully miniscule. It probably hasn't happened yet. If it ever does, the account of that first visit may read like other 'first visits' written by Bernal Diaz del Castillo and Pedro Ciezade Leon (The Conquest of New Spain and The Conquest of Peru). Sullivan013
